M University of Michigan Medical School
[LIST_ITEM] How cells and tissues are arranged in the normal organ system of the body, and
[LIST_ITEM] How these cells and tissues are specialized to perform the function(s) most effectively.
The knowledge gained will hopefully provide a cellular and ultrastructural “framework” for all of the other topics (anatomy, physiology, biochemistry, etc.) that you’ll learn this year.
Histology is also, of course, a FUNDAMENTAL part of PATHOLOGY.
University of Michigan, Histology Slide Collection
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Stabilize cellular structures by chemical fixation.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Dehydrate and infiltrate tissues with paraffin or plastic.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Embed fixed tissues in paraffin or plastic blocks.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Cut into thin slices of 3-10 micrometer thick; collect sections on slides.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Re-hydrate and stain with Hematoxylin (a basic dye): Stains basophilic structures (e.g. nucleic acids) blue/purple.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Counter-stain with Eosin (an acidic dye): Stains acidophilic or “eosinophilic” structures (e.g. proteins, membranes) red/pink.
“H & E” staining is routine, but other dyes and staining techniques may be used to visualize other structures.
[LIST_ITEM] YIELDS A 2-DIMENSIONAL IMAGE CAPABLE OF 0.2 µm RESOLUTION.
[LIST_ITEM] CELLULAR FEATURES ARE STAINED DIFFERENTIALLY BASED PRIMARILY UPON CHEMICAL PROPERTIES.
Gartner and Hiatt. Color Textbook of Histology. 1997. Figure 1.1.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Tissues are fixed with glutaraldehyde (cross-links proteins) and osmium tetraoxide (cross-links lipids); OsO₄ is also an electron-dense "stain"
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Dehydrate and infiltrate tissues w/ plastic.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Embed and block fixed tissues in plastic.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Cut into ultra-thin slices (50 nanometers thick); collect sections on slides.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Stain sections with heavy metal salts (lead citrate and uranyl acetate) that bind nucleic acids & proteins.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Visualize in TEM; heavy metal "stains" block electrons to create contrast
[LIST_ITEM] YIELDS A 2-DIMENSIONAL IMAGE CAPABLE OF 0.2 nm RESOLUTION.
[LIST_ITEM] CELLULAR FEATURES ARE STAINED WITH ELECTRON-DENSE, HEAVY METAL STAINS YIELDING ONLY A BLACK AND WHITE IMAGE
Gartner and Hiatt. Color Textbook of Histology. 1997. Figure 1.1.
The challenge: 3D structures, but viewed only in 2D…
PD-2NEL University of Michigan, Histology Slide Collection
Interpretation of Microscopic Images in Sections
[LIST_ITEM] Glass microscope slides line-scanned using a computer-controlled microscope
[LIST_ITEM] Line scans compiled into single "digital slide" that may be 200k x 200k pixels (that's 40 GIGApixels!)
[LIST_ITEM] Digital slides stored as compressed files (~1.5 GB) and delivered via Web or file-server
[LIST_ITEM] Digital slides viewable as flash objects within web browser or in proprietary format (e.g. Aperio ImageScope)
[LIST_ITEM] Any region of interest on digital slide may be viewed at a range of magnifications with resolution up to 0.25µm/pixel
University of Michigan, Histology Slide Collection
Screenshot of Spectrum WebViewer by Dr. Velkey
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Turn off wireless and connect to network with ethernet cable.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Map network drive (Windows only - click on the link and select "Run").
[NUMBERED_ITEM] If you have problems, try shut down/restart.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Be able to recognize the three major cartilage types in typical light microscopic sections.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Be able to use standard nomenclature to describe a section of cartilage (e.g. chondrocyte, lacuna, matrix, perichondrium).
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Understand the molecular basis for resilience of cartilages.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Be able to recognize forming (embryonic) cartilage.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Be able to describe the process of chondrogenesis.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Hyaline cartilage (W pg 187, 10.1; pg 239, 12.8) hyalce = glass (Greek)
These slides are good examples of mature hyaline cartilage with its abundant
Screenshot of U-M Website by Dr. Velkey
[H1] Microscopes and glass slides still have their place!
[LIST_ITEM] The focal plane and depth-of-field (aperture) of the digital slide is fixed
[LIST_ITEM] The digital slide is only a representative specimen
[LIST_ITEM] Knowing how to use a microscope has its value.
Photo taken by Dr. Sun-Kee Kim
Photo taken by Dr. Sun-Kee Kim
EPITHELIUM CONNECTIVE TISSUE MUSCLE NERVOUS TISSUE (BLOOD)
Basic tissues combine to form larger functional units, called ORGANS.
Epithelial Tissue Connective Tissue Muscle Tissue Peripheral Nervous System Skin / Integumentary System

[LIST_ITEM] Young, et al.: Wheater's Functional Histology, 5th ed. - HIGHLY recommended
[LIST_ITEM] Ross and Pawlina: Histology: A Text and Atlas, 5th ed. - recommended
[H2] Michigan Medical Histology CD – not issued this year (won't work in Mac OS X).
[LIST_ITEM] Usually a total of 8 questions per session divided between weekly quizzes and final exam. Questions will weigh equally.
[LIST_ITEM] Weekly quizzes and final exams will all be administered online.
[LIST_ITEM] Multiple choice questions: some straight text, but MOSTLY image-based (LM, EM, or diagram), or virtual slides
[LIST_ITEM] Sample questions may be found in the online syllabus.
[LIST_ITEM] Shared resources (i.e. MUST stay in locker)
Microsope* Two Boxes of M1 Histology Microscope Slides* Network Cable No MMH CD issued this year
Sign Loan Agreement Sheet – you acknowledge receipt of EACH item and you agree to return them at the end of the year!
[H1] So, what's going to happen in the lab today?
It depends on how you look at it…
[LIST_ITEM] Making sure your computers are set up to access and view virtual slides
[LIST_ITEM] Explanation of the different links to the virtual slides:
[LIST_ITEM] “Load testing” the servers (requires synchronized activity, so wait for instructions)
[LIST_ITEM] After load testing, work through tutorial to learn basic features of ImageScope (Windows) and WebViewer (non-Windows)
[LIST_ITEM] Sign and turn in Loan Agreement Forms acknowledging receipt of network cable (we’ll deal with microscopes and slides NEXT week)
[LIST_ITEM] It is the preferred method of viewing the slides
[LIST_ITEM] Primary advantage is the ability to ANNOTATE slides (for self-study or to mark something about which you have a question)
[LIST_ITEM] Slides are opened into ONE ImageScope window so it's easy to quickly go from one slide to another and/or compare slides side-by-side
[LIST_ITEM] Can adjust image brightness, contrast, and color levels
